item.question:
You received an ASCII file from a good friend of yours who uses the windows OS.
You notice that you see a lot of CR-LF line endings in the file.
How can you remove the CR part from the file?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following commandlines can you use in a BASH shell to make sure the command started in the shell uses the configuration-file top.conf.
Select two.
item.hint: You will need to provide exactly two correct answers. Note that defining a variable and using a variable requires a different syntax. Also note that the question mentions commands started in the shell should be able to read the variable. Hence, the shell should pass the variable to its childs.

item.question: The kernelfile vmlinuz-2.6.18 is in the ________ directory.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer. Note that the question does not explicitly state you should provide the absolute path as well. Your safest bet is to provide the absolute path.

item.question: What best describes the above commandline when executed?
item.choice: <font face="monospace">cat</font> reads from the file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> through stdin and pipes the output to <font face="monospace">grep</font>
<font face="monospace">cat</font> reads the files <font face="monospace"><</font> and <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> and sends the output to <font face="monospace">grep</font>
No output as <font face="monospace">guru1</font> is not a valid username
item.correct_answer: <font face="monospace">cat</font> reads from the file <font face="monospace">/etc/passwd</font> through stdin and pipes the output to <font face="monospace">grep</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You are editing a file in vi and are currently in command-modus.
Which of the following vi-commands will move the cursor 5 lines down and 2 characters to the right?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Your current working directory contains the above files.
Which files are shown when you execute the command ls | grep 't[^o].$'?
Choose all that apply.
item.hint: The command <font face="monospace">grep</font> uses regular expression syntax to specify the match filter. Brackets allow you to specify a set of characters that may occur at a single position. The caret inside brackets means you do not want the specified characters to match at that position. The dot (<font face="monospace">.</font>) means a single random character and the dollar sign (<font face="monospace">$</font>) means end of the line.

item.question: Which of the following statements about symbolic links is true?
item.choice: A symbolic link can be recognized by the character <font face="monospace">l</font> as being the most-left character in the output of <font face="monospace">ls -l</font>.
It is not possible to point a symbolic link to a directory in another filesystem.
The filesize of a symbolic link is always less than 256 bytes.
The command <font face="monospace">find / -type s</font> only displays symbolic links.
A symbolic link does not have its own inode-number.
item.correct_answer: A symbolic link can be recognized by the character <font face="monospace">l</font> as being the most-left character in the output of <font face="monospace">ls -l</font>.
The filesize of a symbolic link is always less than 256 bytes.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which runlevels should you NOT select as default runlevel in /etc/inittab?
Select all answers that apply.
item.hint: The question is not about which runlevels are actually used on a Linux system. The question asks which runlevels you should NOT select in order to get a workable running system.

item.question:
With the command __________ you can display a file in octal format.
Provide only the name of the command.
item.hint: The question asks for only the commandname so providing the path as well, even if correct, is considered a wrong answer.

item.question: What would the file <font face="monospace">/etc/updatedb.conf</font> allow you to do?
item.choice: Exclude directories from being included in the locate-database
Specify the time at wich the locate-database should be updated
Specify which users are allowed to use the <font face="monospace">locate</font> command
item.correct_answer: Exclude directories from being included in the locate-database
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: The command '<font face="monospace">echo $?</font>' will give you what information?
item.choice: The process id of the current shell.
The process id of last executed command.
The exit status of the last executed background command.
The exit status of the last executed foreground command.
item.correct_answer: The exit status of the last executed foreground command.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Considering the command <font face="monospace">dpkg</font> which of the following options are correct?
item.choice: <font face="monospace">-C</font> searches for packages partially installed on the system
item.correct_answer: <font face="monospace">-C</font> searches for packages partially installed on the system
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following commands will do the same as kill -s INT 3022.
Select all that apply.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command can be used to determine the available space on all mounted partitions?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commands will replace all lower case characters with upper case characters?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following device names point to logical partitions?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which option can be used with the shutdown command that will not shutdown the system but will send the warning message that the system will shutdown.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What will the command kill -HUP 134 most likely do?
item.choice: Restart the process 134, re-reading it's config files
Give the process a new process number.
item.correct_answer: Restart the process 134, re-reading it's config files
item.hint: As the question does not say what <font face="monospace">134</font> is you need to know what sending the signal <font face="monospace">HUP</font> will do in general.

item.question:
You want to move all directories and ONLY directories in you current working directory that start with test to the directory testing.
Which of the following commands would be best to perform this task?
item.hint: The question states you want to MOVE the directories which means you can eliminate one answer immediately. The question also states you want to move ONLY directories which eliminates another answer. Now you are left with two possible answers and it comes down to knowing if the command requires an option or not.

item.question: Which of the following commands can be used to examine kernel bootup messages after boot time?
item.hint: Some questions allow multiple answers. Sometimes the question will state how many correct answers are required, in this case not. If you do not know the answer immediately the best strategy is eliminating the answers you know are wrong and select the best answer from the ones that are left. Sometimes another question might give you a clue for a previous question. You can always come back to this question later on.

item.question: Which command will show the last 10 lines of a file by default?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following commandlines allows you to see the difference between the content of
the tar archive and the current content of the directory /home?
item.hint: Even if you never used <font face="monospace">tar</font> in this way you may be able to answer this question correctly by eliminating the wrong answers.

item.question: Which of the following commands makes <font face="monospace">/tmp/myfile</font> readable by everyone but readable/executable only by its owner?
item.hint: If you look at the answers you should see that the exhibit is bogus and you should be able to answer the question without it. Note that the answers cover two commands (i.e. <font face="monospace">chmod</font> and <font face="monospace">chown</font>). If you are in a hurry you might not notice this.

item.question: Which command will show you a list of your previously executed commands?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which file/directory usually has a sticky bit?
item.choice: Every file that needs to stay memory-resident.
item.hint: When the question mentions something in general you must assume how things are done in Debian or RedHat system or specified in the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard.

item.question: Which command will set the the default permissions for new files to <font face="monospace">rw-r-----</font>, regardless of the current setting?
item.hint: Beware that using the numeric notation you specify what <font face="monospace">umask</font> should block. Using the symbolic notation you specify what <font face="monospace">umask</font> should let through.

item.question:
You are searching for the file ring which is owned by user frodo.
Assuming the file is on a mounted filesystem and permissions are sufficient,
which command most likely will display its full path name?
item.hint: The question mentions a mounted filesystem and asks you the most likely command that will find the file. This kind of information is essential to answer this question correctly. If this was not added more answers would be correct. Try to remember the difference between find and locate. That should provide you with enough clues to answer the question correctly.

item.question:
You want the system to shutdown at 17:00 this afternoon. It is now 9:00.
Which of the following commands will shutdown the system at 17:00 and sends out a warning message 20 minutes prior to shutting down?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What will be the result of the above command?
item.choice: Changes directory to the user guru0's home directory
Changes to a directory named <font face="monospace">~guru0</font>
Changes to directory named <font face="monospace">guru0</font> in the current directory
item.correct_answer: Changes directory to the user guru0's home directory
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
When partitioning a disk with more than 1024 cylinders, which of the following could affect the systems ability to boot?
Choose all that apply.
item.choice: The location of the Master Boot Record
Location of the kernel image (<font face="monospace">/boot</font> directory) on the disk
item.correct_answer: Location of the kernel image (<font face="monospace">/boot</font> directory) on the disk
item.hint: This problem occured years ago on systems where the BIOS did not support disks with more then 1024 cylinders. Nowadays you will probably never encounter this problem although Linux is occasionally used on old systems someone has lying around.

item.question: What is the result of the above command?
item.choice: You will get the shell secondary prompt
The text echo ATcomputing will be printed
item.correct_answer: You will get the shell secondary prompt
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: What is a disadvantage of using symbolic links over hard links?
item.choice: A symbolic link becomes disconnected from the underlying file if the file is moved.
A symbolic link can span different filesystems
The hard link uses the same inode as the original file, where a symbolic link has its own inode.
Removing a symbolic link does not remove the underlying file.
item.correct_answer: A symbolic link becomes disconnected from the underlying file if the file is moved.
item.hint: Although you personally might find more than one of the choices a disadvantage, the question is actually which of the following is the most disadvantage.

item.question: Which command would give you a listing of the contents of a tar archive?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You execute the above command.
What will be the result?
item.choice: Only filenames in the user's homedir will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
All directorynames will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
All filenames in the user's homedir and any errors reported by <font face="monospace">find</font> will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
All filenames in the user's homedir will be printed in the terminal and any errors will be written to <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
item.correct_answer: All filenames in the user's homedir and any errors reported by <font face="monospace">find</font> will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will display all the lines of the file <font face="monospace">foo</font> starting with a capital S?
item.hint: The question asks for a regular expression that matches a capital S at the beginning of each line.

item.question:
What would be the correct command to remove the package atop completely from a Debian system?
Select two.
item.hint: By default removing a package under Debian will not remove the configuration files as well.

item.question: Which file is the main configuration file for the init process?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You need to display all files in the current directory that start with at and end with a g.
Choose the best answer.

item.question: According to the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard (FHS), in which directory (full path name) should you look for system logfiles?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: On a Debian system, which command will list all installed packages?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
When you create a new directory, you see the permissions are set to rwx--x---.
Which umask value would cause this to happen?
item.hint: When creating a directory the command <font face="monospace">mkdir</font> asks for a certain set of permissions and <font face="monospace">umask</font> is used to determine what the directory will eventually get. In general, the permissions asked when creating a directory are different from when creating a new file.

item.question:
You want to find the location on the filesystem of the command you previously executed.
Which command would you use?
item.hint: This question is about how Bash finds commands on the filesystem to execute not where a file with a certain name can be found on the filesystem.

item.question:
Consider the above exhibit.
As you can see bar is a symbolic link, pointing to foo.
As user guru1 you execute 'rm bar'.
What happens?
item.choice: Nothing, because <font face="monospace">bar</font> is no ordinary file.
Both <font face="monospace">foo</font> and <font face="monospace">bar</font> would be removed.
Only <font face="monospace">foo</font> would be removed, because <font face="monospace">bar</font> points to <font face="monospace">foo</font>.
You would be asked whether <font face="monospace">bar</font> or <font face="monospace">foo</font> should be removed.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command will produce the above output?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
The user guru1 complains that he cannot access his homedirectory.
Given the directory /home/guru1 has the above permissions.
Which of the following commands would fix this problem?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You want to repeat the last command you executed.
How would you do this?
item.hint: When the shell version is not stated explicitly always assume the question is about Bash.

item.question:
A job is running in the foreground.
Pressing [Ctrl]+[KEY] pauses this job and gives you control of the terminal.
What is [KEY]?
item.hint: The question is about a key combination pressing the control key and another key. The answer you must provide is the letter of the other key.

item.question: What is the meaning of setting the sticky bit permission on a file?
item.choice: nothing, sticky bit has only meaning when set on a directory
the file will be persistent in memory
the file can only be deleted by the owner or a user with root-privileges.
the file can never be deleted by a regular user
item.correct_answer: nothing, sticky bit has only meaning when set on a directory
item.hint: Remember we are talking Linux here.

item.question: Which of the following commands gets its input from <font face="monospace">file1</font>, writes its output to <font face="monospace">file2</font> and writes errormessages to <font face="monospace">file3</font>?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
On a system that has the above uptime.
Which command is best used to print out system boot messages?
item.hint: The kernel keeps the messages in a buffer in memory. This buffer is limited and when full messages are removed using a first in first out algorithm.

item.question:
Consider the above piece of code that uses tabs to indent lines.
Which command will easily convert the tabs to 8 spaces?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Given the above exhibit, which command could you use to bring application 'vi' to the foreground?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
You plugged in a USB DVDROM drive. The dmesg command told you it was detected as device /dev/sr0.
There is no fstab-entry for this device in /etc/fstab.
Which of the following commands can you use to mount the media in that drive to the (existing) directory /mnt/dvdrom?
item.hint: Many questions require you to know which options a command accepts and in which order. This can be very hard to memorize and you may find it difficult to choose between two answers that only differ in the order of their arguments. Fortunately, you can always come back to this question later on. Sometimes another question might give you a clue for a previous question.

item.question:
You are editing the file foo with vi.
You want to save the changes with '[ESC]:w', but vi complains you do not have sufficient rights.
Therefore, you want to check the permissions on that file.
How do you manage this without leaving vi?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commands can you use to create a new file called atcomputing?
item.hint: Although it is not stated explicitly multiple answers may be correct. If there are multiple correct answers you should select all to answer the question correctly.

item.question: Which of the following commands enables write access to the file /usr/share/doc/lpi303/test for users who belong to the group of the file?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question:
Which of the following commands will create an ext3 filesystem on device /dev/sdb3?
Select TWO answers.
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Given the above exhibit, which command could you use to terminate the application 'vi'?
item.hint: Sometimes the correct answer does not fit the question exactly. However, eliminating the wrong answers should lead to the correct answer.

item.question: Which of the following commandlines allows you to cancel a previous issued <font face="monospace">shutdown</font> command?
item.hint: If you are not certain you might get lucky and another question may give you a clue for the correct answer.

item.question: Which command would you use to display how many inodes are available on the <font face="monospace">/home</font> filesystem?
item.hint: The answers only cover the commands <font face="monospace">du</font> and <font face="monospace">df</font>. So choosing the correct command gets you halfway. You will then only need to remember if the command requires an option or not to show the amount of available inodes.
